Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2012 07:23PM 5thSib wrote: I haven't posted in a bit -- chemo has been kicking my butt. Had my 2nd treatment last Tuesday (11th) and just starting to feel a little normal. Mostly nausea (even with all the meds), dizziness, and headache. Now WBC is way low again (back on antibiotics) and they are still telling me to stay out of public places. I've had to do all my Christmas shopping online this year. Regarding surgery, my lumpectomy and SNB was October 11. Most of the feeling has returned under my arm, but I only had one node removed. My lumpectomy site still has soreness, especially my nipple, but I did have an infection there a couple weeks ago. Up until they put me on antibiotics for that, I had a hard lump. It is almost gone now. Hair -- I shaved mine last Wednesday. It was starting to shed pretty badly and my head was very tender. The tenderness went away after I shaved it. I have a bit of a stubble now, though.  For those starting radiation or chemo, check to see if there is a local Look Good Feel Better class you can go to. It is sponsored by the American Cancer Society. They will teach you makeup tips (like creating eyebrows), skin care, and tying scarfs. They give you a kit full of makeup. Take advantage of it if you can.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2013 04:11AM 5thSib wrote: Hello to all my Oct. surgery buddies. It's been a while. I'he been mostly in the triple negative and weekly Taxol groups. I finished chemo last Thursday -- yeah! Next will be rads around middle of May. Connie, congrats on last chemo. Feels great doesn't it? Know what you mean about SE's. Same with me. Mgdsmc, I hear you on chemo. It's rough, yes, but cancer is the enemy. Chemo gives us a fighting chance. We can just hope that one day there will be something easier. I am having some uncomfortable neuropathy right now. Hope it goes away soon. My nails are in various stages of turning loose from the nailbed but I haven't lost any yet. Hair is getting thicker every day. I can actually pinch it between my fingers.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2012 06:45PM 5thSib wrote: Grier, thanks so much for your comments. I have no other sisters with BC (thank goodness the other 3 are safe for now). The other 3 siblings are brothers. One succombed to lung cancer 2 years ago. The other two are in remission from types of lymphoma. I got my receptor results today -- triple negative. My lymph node surgery is scheduled for Nov. 12. I asked my surgeon if I should see an oncologist before the surgery, but he said they would need the results of the remaining lymph nodes to determine treatment. But I am now wondering if I should have more removed than lymph nodes. Oh, and to remove the adhesive -- find someone who sells Mary Kay and purchase the oil free eye makeup remover -- very gentle and works.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2012 05:46AM 5thSib wrote: Connie -- make sure they give you a prescription for some numbing cream for the port especially so soon after getting it in because it might still be a bit tender. I put it on right before left the house (cover with some plastic wrap) and felt nothing when they stuck it. Two days post first chemo. Felt pretty good yesterday but terrible headache and some nausea this morning. May be a work from home day. Hate that my boss I see twice a year is flying in today. Oh well he will be here a week.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2013 08:08PM 5thSib wrote: mgdsmc -- Just wanted to let you know that I did better after this last treatment as they gave me a 7 day patch for the nausea. It did help the nausea not be as bad, and I only had to take an extra pill a couple of times. However, I still had headache and dizziness so still felt really bad for about 7 days. I just have one more AC treatment, then will be going to weekly Taxol. I am hoping it will be better. Thanks for letting us know about the weekly Taxol thread. Does anyone watch Parenthood? One of the main characters is going through breast cancer. Tuesday night's episode was about her shaving her head and her husband making the mistake of going and buying a wig for her. I wasn't sure at first that I wanted to watch, but it was a good episode. You can watch it on NBC.com.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2012 04:45PM 5thSib wrote: Mgdsmc -- looks like I will be getting same drugs as you. AC every other week -- 4 rounds then T weekly for 12 weeks
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2012 03:37PM 5thSib wrote: BetNY22-- I'm right there with you. I start my chemo on 11/26. I bought 2 wigs on Saturday. I had gotten a much shorter than usual cut a couple weeks ago which everyone loved. I found a wig similar to that cut and I wore it to church Sunday and even a very good friend asked if I fixed it different or cut it a little more. She was surprised when she found out it was a wig. I felt self conscious but lots of people told me they loved the new cut. I had my port put in this morning. It is very sore and aches but I refused the pain script because they make me sick. Just taking Advil
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 04:22PM 5thSib wrote: mgdsmc -- With my chemo, they gave me what they called a full-day's dose of Zofran and Emed along with a steroid. Also they told me starting the next morning when I got up to start taking the Zofran pill (4mg) along with a steroid, Dexamethasone (4mg) every 8 hours for a couple days. They also gave me promethazine (25mg) to take for breakthrough nausea. I took it several times. It made me sleep but didn't really help with the nausea. I know part of it is I'm having a hard time drinking while I am nauseated. I try to mostly drink water but it also seems to tate bad for a few days. Maybe I should try to Ensure or Carnation breakfast. I seem to be able to tolerate nuts and peanut butter crackers.  I am starting to feel bad by the time I leave from chemo. I got to thinking that I've always had a hard time tolerating sugar. I am not diabetic, but have had hypoglycemia in the past. Too much sugar gives me headache, dizziness,  nausea. They are pumping glucose into me during the treatment, so I'm wondering if that might be part of what is starting the issue.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2013 04:45AM 5thSib wrote: Paula, just make sure you check your temperature to make sure you don't have a fever. I have ended up with fever two of the 3 treatments and first indication was being chilled.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2013 05:40AM 5thSib wrote: I hope I did not offend anyone with my suggestion about Parenthood. I knew it would not be for everyone, but thought there might be some interested. As I said I was not sure I wanted to watch it, but I did feel it was well done. I'm somewhat struggling with the baldness thing right now. I have 2 wigs and they look great (one of them on in my picture), but I'm really more comfortable in soft hats and scarves. So far the few times I've been at work since I shaved it, I've worn one of the wigs. I plan to be in the office on Monday, and I just can't decide. I would prefer to just wear wear a comfy tobagan with a pretty scarf wrapped around it. But am I going to make people uncomfortable or will they think I'm playing the sympathy card or trying to get attention? We have a small office though and mostly ladies, so I think they would be fine with it. However, we do have visitors coming from our corporate office on Monday, so I guess it might be more appropriate to wear a wig (in other words, I'll probably chicken out and wear the wig). Hope everyone has a great weekend.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2013 06:49PM 5thSib wrote: Mgdsmc -- so glad to hear that you are healing well. Don't worry about the tats. My RO said they will be like a small freckle. A friend showed me hers and really it was not noticeable. I had my last AC yesterday. I put the nausea patch on the day before and they reduced my steroids a little. I feel much better today than I normally do. Hardly any nausea. Still have a headache and a litter dizzy but still not as bad. DH says he can tell a big difference. I will start weekly Taxol in 2 weeks.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2012 05:57PM 5thSib wrote: Mgdsmc -- maybe I missed this but why the 2ND surgery?
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2012 06:19AM 5thSib wrote: Connie -- I agree that this site is great for getting information. Look up HER2 positive in the site search box and you will find information specific to that. As others have said there are targeted therapies that have been developed for HER2+. You will get chemo and  followup therapy that is targeted toward your specific diagnosis. Ask your MO specifically how he treats triple positive differently from HR+, PR+, HER2-. I am triple negative, so that is a question I asked about mine.  I start my chemo tomorrow. Port site is still a bit sore, but hopefully needle stick won't be too bad. I'm a bit nervous but also glad that it's about to start which puts me that much closer to getting on with my life. I plan to continue to work through treatment, but fortunately I have great support in my boss and upper management. They have told me my health is the most important thing and to not try to rush things. Also, I can work from home, so that will help. Unfortunately, the week after my lumpectomy, I lost one of my key employees and now have to start going through interview process. Our HR manager will help, but final interviews and decision will come down to me. Have a Sunday, Ladies.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2013 05:56PM 5thSib wrote: My nails feel kind of like that or like artificial nails. They don't feel like mine. Some are partly loose. I hope none of them come all the way off.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2012 07:59PM 5thSib wrote: I had a lumpectomy on October 11. Also did a SNB. Report during surgery was no cancer in node; however one week later I got the report that there was cancer in the node and now surgeon  says he will have to go back and remove more nodes -- wanted to cry because I bruised and swelled so badly during first surgery (and am still bruised). I don't have a lot of info yet -- path report revealed DCIS, high grade and IDC, grade 3. No receptor results as of yet but my surgeon has been on vacation. I've ended up with an infection from the lumpectomy site and am sore to touch all down my left torso. My PC physican said it had gotten into my lymphatic system. He gave me a strong antibiotic, but I am still sore and my breast is still very purple and hard. It hurts for anything to touch it at all and feels like it is on fire sometimes; other times it just throbs. My surgeon will be back tomorrow so will see if I can get in to see him. I'm trying to read through all these posts from October surgery. It's encouraging to know there are a lot of others out there going through this, but also discouraging to know how many others there are. My sister is a 5 year survivor of breast cancer much more advanced than mine, so that gives me a lot of courage and hope. I'm the 5th of 8 siblings to be diagnosed with some kind of cancer (hence 5thSib). That's really scary to me.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2012 09:22PM 5thSib wrote: I lost my link to this thread and could not remember where/what it was. Finally found the search where I could look for my posts and found you ladies again. I'm behind on readying for sure! I've been hanging out in the triple negative group a lot (helping me be less scared about that diagnosis), but wanted to get back here too. I found out all my "bruising" was blood leaking and the hard knot in my breast is where it clotted. Surgeon said it would eventually go away by itself, but it is sooo sore. I can't stand for anything to touch it. Miserable with or without a bra. Anyone else have this experience. I'm a little over 3 weeks post surgery. Have appointment with RO on Tuesday to discuss a study that says additonal surgery to remove lymph nodes is not necssary as radiation can take care of it, so maybe won't have to have 2nd surgery on Nov. 11. They did tell me that I will need chemo now so will see MO also. Was hoping to avoid that, but things just didn't come out as they had thought pre-surgery.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 08:17PM 5thSib wrote: mgdsmc -- that's for the encouraging words about the chemo. I start on the 26th. I'm trying to catch up on reading posts. I've been busy with decisions and doctors' appointments, paying doctor's bills, etc.  My sister told me my life would be ruled by all this and she was right. I've also been on the triple negative site more trying to find out as much as I can about that type of breast cancer since that is what I have. Somewhat discouraging to go from being told lumpectory, then just radiation and maybe a pill to keep it from recurring before surgery to being told, aggressive, hard to treat, chemo, and no pill that wil help with recurrence after surgery. Planning on looking at wigs on Saturday. It might actually be kind of nice to not have to worry about fixing my hair in the morning and just pulling on a wig -- will make getting ready for work quicker.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2012 07:48PM 5thSib wrote: Mgdsmc -- hope everything goes well with the surgery tomorrow. Glad to see daughter is getting things ready for you. I was extremely sore for a couple of days after my port was installed, but just used Tylenol (and Tylenol PM at night) and that worked pretty well. It stayed tender for over a week, but it is finally starting to not bother me at all. My headache lasted all day Wednesday (stayed in bed) and some of today. Nurse said it was probably the Neulasta shot -- said some people get headaches from it. I haven't really had any bone pain from it. They have me taking Zyrtec twice a day for 5 days to combat that. I just still feel a bit slightly nauseated and having to make myself eat and drink. I'm hoping I feel better tomorrow.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2012 07:57PM 5thSib wrote: BetNY22 -- besides the baking soda try Biotene toothpaste and mouthwash. The nurse recommended it to me and I think it really helped.
